text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Greek Cypriot press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Britain blames Ankara for impasse reached at Glion, Switzerland, during latest talks between Greek Cypriot leader Glafcos Clerides and Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash.
- Security Council will avoid pointing finger at any side when U.N. envoy Diego Cordovez briefs it tomorrow on outcome of Glion talks.
- Diego Cordovez puts on brave face during discussions in London on stalemate resulting from Glion talks.
- Police say hit man who murdered Turkish Cypriot in Limassol on Saturday may have been member of Turkish secret services.
- Communist Akel calls for meeting of National Council to discuss Turkish threats of partial integration of occupied areas with Ankara.
- Accreditation council for tertiary education which ended assessment work on Monday approved 46 fields of study offered in private sector, rejected 15 and pinpointed weaknesses in 34.
- Nicosia and Athens expected to take crucial decisions in forthcoming days on ways to break impasse on Cyprus problem.
- Tourist infrastructure in Paphos and Limassol will be improved by repairing pavements and renovating old buildings.
- Athens and Nicosia develop intense diplomatic activity in New York ahead of discussions at U.N. Security Council on Cyprus on Wednesday.
